Sentence: Cheveley, an enemy of Lady Chiltern's from their school days, attempts to blackmail Sir Robert into supporting a fraudulent scheme to build a canal in Argentina

Cheveley's dead mentor, Baron Arnheim, convinced the young Sir Robert many years ago to sell him (Robert) a Cabinet secret, a secret that suggested he (Robert) buy stocks in the Suez Canal three days before the British government announced its purchase
Cheveley has the letter to prove his (Robert) crime
Fearing both the ruin of career and marriage, Sir Robert submits to her (Cheveley) demands

Cheveley pointedly informs Lady Chiltern of Sir Robert's change of heart regarding the canal scheme, the morally inflexible Lady, unaware of both her (Lady) husband's past and the blackmail plot, insists that Sir Robert renege on his (Robert) promise
Cheveley and admit his (Robert) guilt to his (Robert) wife
Incensed at Sir Robert's reneging on his (Robert) promise, she (Cheveley) ultimately exposes Sir Robert to his (Robert) wife once they are both in the room
Cheveley makes a proposal: claiming to still love Goring from their early days of courtship, she (Cheveley) offers to exchange Sir Robert's letter for her (Cheveley) old beau's hand in marriage
Vengefully she (Cheveley) plans to send it to Sir Robert misconstrued as a love letter addressed to the dandified lord
